Topic.Title: ARM chips found in 95 percent of cellphones

Message.Msg: Did you figure it out Einstein? I love it - IBM - the " spiritual" leader of ARM ecosystem But because of fin height variability, there are fears that the foundries could struggle making bulk finFETs. “People are just waking up to this,” said Gary Patton, vice president of the Semiconductor Research and Development Center at IBM. The foundries should take a harder look at silicon-on-insulator (SOI) technology, which can reduce fin height variability, Patton said. And because there are fewer process steps with SOI-based finFETs, the traditional cost penalty associated with SOI disappears, he added.

Topic.Title: ARM + TSMC leading Intel in SOC technology

Message.Msg: Okay, first you go with stupid and then you double down. You sound just like the ARM fanboi. ARM's 28nm isn't equivalent to Intel's 22nm. Go listen to the Pacific Crest presentation if you want to hear the explanation. It doesn't have FinFET. And Intel will quickly move to 14nm. Intel is eliminating the delay on bringing each node to the Atom family. So, ARM isn't going to catch up - they are going to drop further behind. It will be at least 4 years before ARM has 16nm volume production. Intel will be doing 7nm by then and will own mobility. And will be working on 5nm. This isn't about averages and equal motivation. It's about science, technology and manufacturing. ARM and Intel aren't even now in technology. Intel has a huge lead and it's getting larger. But the good news is your ignorance of fabrication qualifies you for a job as an analyst with one of the big firms on Wall Street. You could be the next James Covello. He's been doubling down on stupid for years...

Message.Title: Durable goods rise in July on Boeing orders
Message.Msg: The Commerce Department said on Friday durable goods orders jumped 4.2 percent on strong demand for civilian aircraft after an upwardly revised 1.6 percent increase in June. Last month's increase was the largest since December. Economists polled by Reuters had forecast orders for durable goods, items from toasters to aircraft that are meant to last at least three years, rising 2.4 percent after a previously reported 1.3 percent increase in June. http://www.reuters.com/article/2012/08/24/us-durable-goods-idUSBRE87N0IX20120824
someone must know something it sure in the F isn't ww

Message.Title: Intel leads way for finFET chips as competitors play catch-up
Message.Msg: FinFET is a loosely used general term in the field to describe any fin-based, multigate transistor architecture regardless of the number of gates and aspect ratio. Intel is clearly the leader in this technology and the rest of the industry is playing catch-up as they recognize the comparative benefits. Its manufacturing center in Chandler, Arizona is producing the world’s most advanced finFET technology. Microchip foundries across the world are in the process of making a transition toward this architecture, from 2D to 3D chip designs, at the 14nm node size. The list of companies includes but is not limited to: IBM and Global Foundaries, based in the US, and UMC, TSMC and Samsung, based in southeast Asia. However, the major difference is that many of these companies are hesitant to be all-in on the new design for technical and capital cost reasons and are considering hybrid approaches that would incorporate elements of the basic Intel design at the front-end of the manufacturing process flow while utilizing pre-existing technology for the back-end of the flow. The trade-off is the loss of the full manufacturing cost reduction of the device node size shrink at 14nm using the more advanced 3D design. Another major challenge for companies in the implementation of finFET devices at ~14nm is reduced process control due to an increasing density of non-visual defects. Non-visual defects are ones that do not scatter light and are not detectable by current optical or electron beam inspection tools. According to a recent publication this week by Qcept Technologies, which focuses on defect issues in semiconductor clean rooms, up to 30 percent of yield loss in today’s fabs are not traceable to physical defects. What’s more, microchip manufacturers are seeking to automate more of their inspection steps in order to reduce overhead, which causes more of a quandary for metrology equipment suppliers. In summary, Intel is revolutionizing advanced microprocessor chip architecture in the transition from traditional 2D to a 3D finFET design, and its global competitors are actively seeking ways to follow this roadmap. http://www.examiner.com/article/intel-leads-way-for-finfet-chips-as-competitors-play-catch-up

Message.Title: Take That Apple!!!
Message.Msg: Acer Aspire V5 review: an 11-inch Ivy Bridge laptop for $550 ($500 with Acer's current promotion) Acer first took the wraps off its Aspire V5 series at CeBIT in March, teasing the line of notebooks with designs that are 30 percent thinner than other laptops in their category. A few months later, in June, the company officially unveiled the 14- and 15-inch Aspire V5s, with Ivy Bridge processors and prices starting at $630. Rounding out that family is the 11-inch the Aspire V5 171. We have a bit of an identity crisis on our hands with this guy: though it looks like a netbook and weighs a light three pounds, it packs a Core i5 Ivy Bridge processor befitting a full-fledged machine, but it costs a budget-minded $550 ($500 with Acer's current promotion). http://www.engadget.com/2012/08/23/acer-aspire-v5-review/

Message.Title: Take That Apple!!!
Message.Msg: Acer Aspire V5 review: an 11-inch Ivy Bridge laptop for $550 ($500 with Acer's current promotion). http://www.engadget.com/2012/08/23/acer-aspire-v5-review/

Topic.Title: Examining Intel's Guerilla Approach To The Smartphone Sector

Message.Msg: My comments were about the article... The author was over-thinking...

This laptop will normally go for $550, but Acer is kicking things off with a $50 discount through Facebook. The already-available $600 Aspire V5 171-6616 is identically configured but isn't available with the $50-off promotion. But let's talk options. Look at other 11-inch laptops on the market, and you'll quickly see that the Aspire V5 stacks up quite well. While most machines pack AMD chipsets, Acer's model runs an Ivy Bridge CPU and offers 500GB of storage. But let us elaborate -- here's a look at some comparable machines. If you're in the market for an 11-inch notebook, the Aspire V5-171-6869 is a solid contender. Sony's 11-inch, $450 VAIO E is worth a gander, as it offers comparable specs in a new "wrap" design. (The best way to describe it is that the laptop looks like a briefcase when closed.) The processor is only a dual-core AMD E2-1800, but other specs match up with the V5's: a 500GB hard drive and a 1,366 x 768 screen, though 4GB versus 6GB of RAM. If you're open to an AMD chip, you might also consider the HP Pavilion dm1z, which for $505 offers a 500GB hard drive and 6GB of RAM. Though this machine was announced with a Core i3 CPU, only the AMD option remains available here in the US. And while the dm1z is a tad heavier than the Aspire V5 (3.2 versus 3.05 pounds), we like its patterned lid -- and the optional red color scheme. We recently singled out Samsung's Series 3 11-incher in our back-to-school roundup. For $450, you get a Core i3-380M processor in a sleek, 2.66-pound body with a sweet block-color design. Still, you only get 320GB of storage, and the CPU belongs to Intel's older Arrandale architecture. Since the 11-inch Aspire V5 has some internals in common with larger laptops, it's worth considering models with larger displays. The HP dv4, configured to match the V5 with a Core i5 CPU, 6GB of RAM and a 500GB hard drive, goes for $655, but the entry-level model with 4GB of RAM and a second-gen Core-i3 processor costs $530. Unlike the V5, this machine boasts an optical drive, but it does weigh a heftier 4.79 pounds. Finally, there's the Dell Inspiron 15R, which packs a Core i5 Ivy Bridge CPU, 6GB of RAM, 500GB and full versions of Adobe Photoshop Elements and Premiere Elements for $600. Again, you're looking at a heavier machine -- 6.05 pounds in this case -- but the extra screen real estate and larger six-cell battery may make it worth it for some.
Sweet. The cheaper Intel products get, the cheaper the share price gets....

Message.Msg: <<<it's HUGE advantage to a CPU architecture when every company on the planet, except one, is supporting it !! Didn't you post a few months back that Intel was the largest ARMH customer? BTW, what's with the "Everybody" and "All" statements? It biases your argument because it can be so easily proven untrue.

OK, Im not sure what you're trying to say or if you even understand what I proposed. > INtel can crush any single company...< TSM is comparable to INTC in enterprise value. Smaller, yes, but not hugely different in size. TSM won't be easily 'crushed'. I'm talking about TSM here, NOT ARMH. ARMH is really at the mercy of foundries in the end, and that is the crux of their problem. > ARM's strength is in numbers...< Yes, and if TSM became the sole supplier of ARMH-based SOC's (or at least of the most advanced technology chips, with lower performance designs continuing to be licensed out to all foundries as part of an anti-trust arrangement that I think would have to happen), TSM could lever that strength as the dominant ARMH-based IDM company in the mobile computing market. This move would head off INTC's push into the mobile space, and would place TSM in direct challenge to INTC in it, but in this case (unlike in the case or AMD vs. INTC in CPU's), with TSM-ARMH as the leader.

Message.Title: Just A Thought
Message.Msg: The RSIs of many of the major indexes were above 80 before yesterday's pullback. That indicated a significantly overbought condition. It will take more pullbacks to eliminate that condition. With the Fed leaning toward a new QE, some retreatment in the stock market can only help the Fed to pull the trigger. With that said, although a new QE is likely to have a short term positive effect on stock prices, it may not help the market in a long run. In addition, there are still unresolved negative technical divergences between the price levels of the major indexes and the market internals. Should they remain unresolved, it could spell trouble for stock prices in the long run. The major indexes are at the level they are mostly due to expectations of QEs. The fundamental picture is murky. have a nice day.......... by Yin Lin, CFA

Message.Msg: Intel REDUCES Power Consumption and 4 Heavily Traded Shares Rounding Out the Week By Leah Powell | More Articles August 24, 2012 Intel Corporation (NASDAQ:INTC) has teamed with South Korean telecom company KT Corporation for the development of energy-efficient technology for the reduction of power consumption at data centers, according to news reports. The new system, if it is applied to every KT-owned center, would save about 8.6 billion won ($7.6 million) annually, according to Korea Times. Implementing the new system in every data center in South Korea could save as much as 44.8 billion won ($39.6 million).

Message.Title: New twist in Intel, ARM server war: Interconnects
Message.Msg: http://www.eetimes.com/electronics-news/4394625/New-twist-in-Intel--ARM-server-war-interconnect Red the last comment and googled Ethernet (40G, 100G, 400G) Intel 22nm and what showed up? 8/24/2012 8:58 AM EDT Intel is clearly has a plan for interconnect evolution,(IDF may give us more insight) with recent acquisitions, we will very likely see Ethernet (40G, 100G, 400G) and Infiniband continue to be the leaders. Both are a decade ahead on Bandwidth, latency is not a issue if your 4 to 10 times the data rate, (ie RapidIO is only 10G) Network Adapters and switches will be integrated into the processor or/and Chipset, and in many cases already are. Netronome introduced its 200 Gbps NFP-6xxx family of network flow processors based on Intel’s 22nm 3-D TriGate technology and designed for high-performance networking applications that require programmable, line-rate, stateful processing on millions of simultaneous, complex flows. The devices deliver full L2-L7 processing on both packets and flows, with 120 cores being devoted to flow processing and 96 cores for packet processing. The company claims over six times the packet processing performance at less than half the power compared to 28nm-based processing alternatives. http://www.convergedigest.com/Bandwidth/newnetworksarticle.asp?ID=35983 seems to fit into Intel server road map any thoughts?

Message.Title: Samsung Guilty-AAPL Up Big After Hours
Message.Msg: Does this bode well for INTC?

The leveling off after October is caused by the timing of the dividend. The dividend causes the puts to increase in value (should have more premium) and the calls to decrease in value (should have less premium) when the price is adjustted. This could even be the start of a dividend arbitrage play since there is also 32k Nov. $27 strike volume. 16k Oct $28 calls traded for about 8 cents each. 32k Nov $27 calls traded for 31 to 33 cents each. It looks like these two might be linked. You just have to figure out if the person bought/sold the October calls and if they bought/sold the Novemeber calls.
